citations.narrative:
Two guinea pig enclosures are not providing the minimum required space for the number of animals that are currently
housed inside of them.
-Thirteen guinea pigs are housed in a glass walled primary enclosure that measures 34 inches by 30 inches providing a
total of 1,020 square inches of floor space. The guinea pigs are over 350 grams and therefore require 101 square inches
each (or 1,313 square inches for this group of thirteen).
-Fifteen guinea pigs are housed in a glass walled primary enclosure that measures 34 inches by 30 inches providing a
total of 1,020 square inches of floor space. There are eight guinea pigs that are over 350 grams and seven guinea pigs
that are under 350 grams. This group of guinea pigs requires 101 square inches each for guinea pigs over 350 grams and
60 square inches each for guinea pigs under 350 grams (or 1,228 square inches for this group of fifteen).
Not providing the minimum area of space does not allow for adequate freedom of movement, exercise, or reduce the
potential for injury due to overcrowding or competition between the guinea pigs. All guinea pigs of this size must be
provided at least the minimum required floor space (101 square inches for each guinea pig weighing > 350 grams and 60
square inches for each guinea pig weighing < 350 grams) in their primary enclosure.

The upstairs breeding enclosures for Syrian hamsters are not providing the minimum required interior height of six inches.
The enclosures are plastic bins measuring less than 4.5 inches tall from the outside.
Not providing the minimum height does not allow for adequate freedom of movement which can which can lead to
inadequate exercise, discomfort, stress, and incompatibility. All hamsters must be provided at least the minimum required
height (6 inches) in their primary enclosure.
To be corrected by August 1, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
